--- title: "Grammar of data visualization" subtitle: "Lecture 2" date: "2025-01-16" format: revealjs: output-file: 02-data-grammar-slides.html auto-stretch: false --- ## Reminders {.smaller} - I have office hours today! 1:00-3:00 PM in Old Chemistry 203/203B. - We will start grading your ae repositories next week - make sure you have them ready to go. - First 'real' lab is on Monday; the topic will be data visualization (what we are starting today). ## Outline {.smaller} - Last time: - We introduced you to the course toolkit. - You **cloned** your `ae` repositories and started making some updates in your Quarto documents. - You **commited and pushed** your changes back. . . . - Today: - We will introduce data visualization. - You will **pull** to get today's application exercise file. - You will work on the new application exercise on data visualization, **commit** your changes, and **push** them. # From last time ## `ae-01-meet-the-penguins` ::: appex Go to RStudio, confirm that you're in the `ae` project, and open the document `ae-01-meet-the-penguins.qmd`. ::: ## Common problems: {.smaller} - The environment used by Quarto ***when rendering*** starts EMPTY - it does *not see* what *you see* in your environment. \ - Using functions that cause a popup (like `View()` ) are *not going to work* when you render a document. Either use a comment (with `#`) to remove them, or just delete before rendering!\ - Make sure you commit and then PUSH! Just committing is not enough! # Data visualization ## Thoughts on this plot? ![](images/02/female-heights.png) ## More Penguins {.smaller} ![](images/02/peng_plot.png) ## Start plotting! How can you create something like this???
If there is one thing you take away from today: We ❤️ `ggplot()` ! ## Load packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(palmerpenguins) library(tidyverse) library(ggthemes) ``` ::: ## Look at the data ![](images/df.png) ## Visualize the data What are some steps you can take to visualize a data set? - What do you want on the x-axis? - What do you want on the y-axis? ## Step 1. Prepare a canvas for plotting ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = penguins) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 2. Map variables to aesthetics {.smaller} *Map* `year` to the `x` *aesthetic* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 3. Map variables to aesthetics {.smaller} *Map* `percent_yes` to the `y` *aesthetic* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## So... what are aesthetics?? {.smaller} - **Aesthetics** are visual properties of a plot that are mapped to from **variables** - Some common aesthetics: - **x** and **y** axes - color - fill - size - shape ## Argument names {.smaller} It's common practice in R to omit the names of first two arguments of a function: . . . - Instead of ``` r ggplot(data = your_data, mapping = aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) ``` - Use ``` r ggplot(your_data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) ``` ## Step 4. Represent data on your canvas {.smaller} with a `geom` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 4. Represent data on your canvas {.smaller} - Adding `geom_point()` resulted in the following warning: ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_point()`) ``` ## Step 5. Map variables to aesthetics {.smaller} *Map* `species` to the `color` *aesthetic* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 6. Represent data on your canvas {.smaller} with another `geom` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Warnings and messages - Adding `geom_smooth()` resulted in the following warning: ``` `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x' ``` . . . - It tells us the type of smoothing ggplot2 does under the hood when drawing the smooth curves that represent trends for each species. . . . - Going forward we'll suppress this warning to save some space. ## Step 7. Split plot into facets {.smaller} When you hear 'facet', think 'sub-plots'! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(~island) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 7. Split plot into facets {.smaller} You have options! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + facet_wrap(~species) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## A note on facets: {.smaller} More is not always better! Which plot do you think made it easier to compare between penguin species? ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 8. Use a different color scale ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_canva() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 8. Use a different color scale ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 9. Apply a different theme ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 9. Apply a different theme ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + theme_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 9. Apply a different theme ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + theme_solarized() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 9. Apply a different theme ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 10. Add labels ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", color = "Species", title = "Penguin Body Mass vs. Bill Length") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 11. Set transparency of points with `alpha` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.1) + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", color = "Species") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 11. Set transparency of points with `alpha` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7) + geom_smooth() + scale_color_colorblind() + labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", color = "Species") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## Step 12. Hide standard errors of curves with `se = FALSE` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, mapping = aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, color = species)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.5) + geom_smooth(se = FALSE) + scale_color_colorblind() + labs(x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Body Mass (g)", color = "Species") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](02-data-grammar_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=864} ::: ::: ## How am I supposed to remember all of this?! {.smaller} ***You aren't!!!*** - It's important to (eventually) know and remember the key ideas: what does changing a theme do? What are aesthetics? What is a geom? - You do *not* need to memorize a comprehensive list of *all* of the different geoms, themes, color scales, etc. - There will be a few fundamentals we expect you to know - more on that later! ## Grammar of graphics {.smaller} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} We built a plot layer-by-layer - just like described in the book *The Grammar of Graphics* and - implemented in the **ggplot2** package, the data visualization package of the tidyverse. ::: ::: {.column width="20%"} ![](images/02/gg-book.png) ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](images/02/gg-layers.png) ::: ::: # Application exercise What if we want to use our own data? - `read_csv("data_file.csv")` (assuming the data is in a CSV format) # Application exercise ## `ae-02-bechdel-dataviz` {.smaller} ::: appex - Go to your `ae` project in RStudio. - Make sure all of your changes up to this point are committed and pushed, i.e., there's nothing left in your Git pane. - If you haven't yet done so, click **Pull** to get today's application exercise file. - Work through the application exercise in class, and **render, commit, and push** your edits by the end of class. ::: ## Recap {.smaller} - Construct plots with `ggplot()`. - Layers of ggplots are separated by `+`s. - The formula is (almost) always as follows: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(DATA, aes(x = X-VAR, y = Y-VAR, ...)) + geom_XXX() ``` ::: ## Coming Up... {.smaller} - What are some other types of plots you can make? - How can you talk about the information conveyed by plots?
